metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: The three most used methods for drawing rectangles in canvas are:
content.html: The three most used methods for drawing rectangles in canvas are:

content.text: The rect() method defines a rectangle.
The rect() method has the following parameters:

content.code_html:
Parameter Description
x The x-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the rectangle
y The y-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the rectangle
width The width of the rectangle, in pixels
height The height of the rectangle, in pixels

content.code:
<script>const canvas = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d");

ctx.rect(10,10, 150,100);
ctx.stroke();</script>
content.code_html:
<script>
const canvas = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d");

ctx.rect(10,10, 150,100);
ctx.stroke();
</script>

content.text: Notice that the rect() method does not draw the rectangle (it just defines it). So, in addition, you have to use the stroke() method (or the fill() method) to actually draw it.
content.html: Notice that the rect() method does not draw the rectangle (it just defines it). So, in addition, you have to use the stroke() method (or the fill() method) to actually draw it.

content.text: The fillRect() method draws a filled rectangle.
The fillRect() method has the following parameters:

content.code_html:
Parameter Description
x The x-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the rectangle
y The y-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the rectangle
width The width of the rectangle, in pixels
height The height of the rectangle, in pixels

content.text: The fill-color is specified with the fillStyle property. If the fillStyle property is not set, the fill-color defaults to black.
content.html: The fill-color is specified with the fillStyle property. If the fillStyle property is not set, the fill-color defaults to black.

content.code:
<script>const canvas = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d");

ctx.fillRect(10,10, 150,100);
</script>
content.code_html:
<script>
const canvas = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d");

ctx.fillRect(10,10, 150,100);
</script>

content.code:
<script>const canvas = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d");
ctx.fillStyle = "pink";
ctx.fillRect(10,10, 150,100);
</script>
content.code_html:
<script>
const canvas = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d");

ctx.fillStyle = "pink";
ctx.fillRect(10,10, 150,100);
</script>

content.text: The strokeRect() method draws a stroked (outlined) rectangle.
The strokeRect() method has the following parameters:

content.code_html:
Parameter Description
x The x-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the rectangle
y The y-coordinate of the upper-left corner of the rectangle
width The width of the rectangle, in pixels
height The height of the rectangle, in pixels

content.text: The stroke-color is specified with the strokeStyle property. If the strokeStyle property is not set, the stroke-color defaults to black.
content.html: The stroke-color is specified with the strokeStyle property. If the strokeStyle property is not set, the stroke-color defaults to black.

content.code:
<script>const canvas = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d");

ctx.strokeRect(10,10, 150,100);
</script>
content.code_html:
<script>
const canvas = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d");

ctx.strokeRect(10,10, 150,100);
</script>

content.code:
<script>const canvas = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d");
ctx.strokeStyle = "blue";
ctx.strokeRect(10,10, 150,100);
</script>
content.code_html:
<script>
const canvas = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d");

ctx.strokeStyle = "blue";
ctx.strokeRect(10,10, 150,100);
</script>

content.code:
<script>const canvas = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d");

// Red rectangle
ctx.beginPath();
ctx.lineWidth = "6";
ctx.strokeStyle = "red";
ctx.rect(5, 5, 290, 140);
ctx.stroke();

// Green rectangle
ctx.beginPath();
ctx.lineWidth = "4";
ctx.strokeStyle = "green";
ctx.rect(30, 30, 50, 50);
ctx.stroke();

// Blue rectangle
ctx.beginPath();
ctx.lineWidth = "10";
ctx.strokeStyle = "blue";
ctx.rect(50, 50, 150, 80);
ctx.stroke();</script>
content.code_html:
<script>
const canvas = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d");

// Red rectangle
 ctx.beginPath();
ctx.lineWidth = "6";
ctx.strokeStyle = "red";
ctx.rect(5, 5, 290, 140);
ctx.stroke();

// Green rectangle
 ctx.beginPath();
ctx.lineWidth = "4";
ctx.strokeStyle = "green";
ctx.rect(30, 30, 50, 50);
ctx.stroke();

// Blue rectangle
 ctx.beginPath();
ctx.lineWidth = "10";
ctx.strokeStyle = "blue";
ctx.rect(50, 50, 150, 80);
ctx.stroke();
</script>

content.code:
<script>const canvas = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d");

// Red rectanglectx.lineWidth = "6";ctx.strokeStyle = "red";
ctx.strokeRect(5, 5, 290, 140); // Green rectanglectx.lineWidth =
"4";ctx.strokeStyle = "green";ctx.strokeRect(30, 30, 50, 50);
// Blue rectanglectx.lineWidth = "10";ctx.strokeStyle = "blue";
ctx.strokeRect(50, 50, 150, 80);</script>
content.code_html:
<script>
const canvas = document.getElementById("myCanvas");
const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d");

// Red rectangle
ctx.lineWidth = "6";
ctx.strokeStyle = "red";
ctx.strokeRect(5, 5, 290, 140);

// Green rectangle
ctx.lineWidth = "4";
ctx.strokeStyle = "green";
ctx.strokeRect(30, 30, 50, 50);

// Blue rectangle
ctx.lineWidth = "10";
ctx.strokeStyle = "blue";
ctx.strokeRect(50, 50, 150, 80);
</script>
